text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chocolate snow cap cookies
that's right what's better than a
chocolate cookie one that looks like
it's topped with delicious snow and this
is definitely one instance where crack
is not whack in fact it's critical to
the look of these classic holiday
cookies so let me show you how to make
these and as usual I'm going to say
they're pretty easy so for step one
we're going to get our dry ingredients
together which means in a bowl I'm going
to dump some all-purpose flour along
with some very high quality cocoa check
the blog I'll tell you which one I used
we're also going to need some salt and
some baking powder what's that you
mistakenly use baking soda that's why it
didn't work so make sure you're using
baking powder and we're going to take a
whisk and we're going to mix that up
thoroughly and we're just going to set
that aside until needed all right so
that's done next up we're going to melt
some chocolate over some hot water just
put that on low put that bowl on top and
just let it sit there until it melts
completely and of course if you put a
little too much chocolate in you must
adjust there that's perfect now okay so
we're let that chocolate sit over hot
water until it's melted and at that
point we can start our batter so in the
stand mixer I have some room temperature
butter we're going to add some brown
sugar and as you can see we have our
paddle attachment and we're going to go
ahead and what's called cream the butter
and the sugar together which simply
means mix it together for a couple
minutes until it looks like a paste like
this and then we're going to add two
whole eggs but one at a time alright so
crack one in turn the mixer on as soon
as that one's incorporated then you can
add the second egg okay because eggs are
almost all water and the mixture in
there is almost all fat those don't like
to mix so if you add both eggs together
it could separate so one at a time and
once that second egg is mixed in
completely we're to go ahead and grab
our bowl of melted chocolates and
assuming you haven't just simply chugged
it we're going to pour that into the
mixer we'll give that a quick mix and
then as soon as that melted chocolate is
incorporated we'll stop and add the dry
ingredients but before we do give the
sides of scrape and the paddle or you
want to clean it off so everything mixes
in nicely and then go ahead and pour
your dry mixture in you want to start on
a slow speed so you're not wearing the
stuff and we're just going to give that
a brief mix until basically those dry
ingredients kind of disappear or almost
and then
scrape that mixture into a bowl because
before we work with this we have to
chill it thoroughly so go ahead and wrap
that in plastic and then throw in their
fridge for about an hour or until it's
firm enough to scoop which this is oh
yeah thats scoopable sure you can use a
plain old spoon if you want but you know
I love my little survey scoop so I can
get perfectly sized cookies every time
and as we scoop these we're going to
drop them into a bowl of powdered sugar
so drop it in roll it around and once
it's completely coated with sugar pick
it up and roll it in your palm to make a
perfectly round ball and once you've
rolled it we're going to go back into
the sugar for another coating the key to
this recipe as you will see is a ton of
powdered sugar on the outside oh by the
way not to spoil the ending we see how I
shake off the excess here a little bit
that was a mistake but as usual my
mistakes will benefit you you'll see
what happens later but anyway you're
going to coat your balls thoroughly in
powdered sugar we're going to place
those on our cookie sheet I line mine
with a baking mat but you can use
parchment and we're going to go ahead
and bake those in the center of a 350
degree oven for about 12 minutes or
until they look like chocolate snowcap
cookies
check it out those look pretty good or
at least that's what I thought but
anyway we'll get into that so we're
going to take those out they're going to
be very very very soft when they first
come out so let them sit on the cookie
sheet for about 10 minutes to firm up a
little bit before you try to transfer
them onto your cooling rack but after
about 10 minutes they should transfer
easily so I transferred those onto my
rack and as I waited for them to cool I
realized they're not as snowy as I
wanted
I don't want dingy March snow I want
brilliant white January snow so as he
sat that beautiful white snow kind of
faded a little bit which made me a
little sad until I tasted them and they
were so unbelievably delicious
chocolatey fudgy just absolutely
beautifully textured I kind of forgot
about the appearance and simply enjoyed
its chocolatey fudgy goodness but as
soon as I finished I knew I needed to do
one more test so I did two things I let
the dough chill overnight I scooped out
another small test batch but except this
time I did not knock off any of that
excess powdered sugar I really really
really piled it on how much remember
that scene in Scarface that's how much
and then I cooked this batch exactly the
same three
fifty-four about 12 minutes and I
noticed two things the dough that sat
overnight sat up higher it didn't spread
out as much and because I coated them an
even more powdered sugar they actually
came out way whiter as you can see so
the moral of the story here is if you
want chocolate snowcap cookies that
actually look like snow caps you have to
go Tony Montana on these and make sure
they have a super thick layer of that
powdered sugar before you bake them you
almost literally can't put too much on
there okay
but anyway wintery appearances aside
these really were great chocolate
cookies and I'm sure would be a huge hit
at any any holiday cookie exchange so I
really do hope you give these a try
head over to food wishes calm for all
the ingredients and more info as usual
and as always enjoy
